Graphical abstract Ordered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 materials with high specific area were synthesized by evaporation–induced self–assembly (EISA) method. CeNb/TiSi catalysts were prepared via impregnation method and evaluated for catalytic elimination of 1,2-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB). The structures and properties of CeNb/TiSi were controlled by adjusting Ti/Si and Ce/Nb molar ratios and characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, TEM, Raman, XPS and temperature-programmed technology. Results showed that Ce and Nb oxides were highly dispersed on the surface of TiO2-SiO2 carriers due to its high specific surface area. Nb oxides was not only contributed to moderate and strong acid sites but also conducive to the catalytic elimination of o-DCB. Weak acid sites mainly derived from hydroxyl on the surface of Si. The catalyst without Si exhibited an optimum elimination efficacy of o-DCB but bad stability due to the deposition of Cl−, while the sample with high content of Si had excellent stability on account of the preferable chlorine-resistant ability of Si in catalytic elimination reaction o-DCB. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism of o-DCB catalytic elimination was proposed, in which surface lattice oxygen played a role of redox sites. Keywords Catalytic oxidation Ordered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 CeNb oxides 1,2-Dichlorobenzene 1 Introduction As an all-purpose organic solvent and chemical building block, chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) mainly come from waste incineration, industrial activity involving chlorine, and pesticide production [1–3]. The particular structure of CVOCs let them steadily exist in eco-environment and hard to degrade. The enrichment of CVOCs in the body of humans would result in cancer and aberration [4–6], and they will cause ozone layer destruction, photochemical smog and global warming in atmosphere [7]. Thus, the elimination and clean emissions of exhaust gas is indispensable. In the filed of heterogeneous catalysis, many researchs have been performed in decompostion of CVOCs. Vanadium based catalysts are firstly used to destruct CVOCs due to its excellent catalytic performance and stability, and its have been applied in industry nowadays [8–10]. However, the shortcoming that vanadium oixde is poisonous to biology is also nonnegligible [11]. The production and employ of vanadium based catalysts and treatment of waste catalysts problbaly bring about secondary pollution to ecological environment [12]. Therefore, the estabilish of non-vanadium catalysts to destruct CVOCs becomes a hot point. Zhou et al. [13] studied the influence of CeO2–TiO2 catalysts on catalytic elimination of CVOCs, and they found that the specific surface area of CeO2–TiO2 catalysts and the interaction betweeen Ce and Ti played a signifiant role in catalytic oxidation of 1,2-dichloroethane. Kan et al. [14] investigated catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene over Mn-Ce/cordierite catalyst, and the T90 of chlorobenzene oxidation was 350 °C. Additionally, Co, Cr, and Fe oxide catalysts are also extensively researched in catalytic oxidation of CVOCs [15–17]. However, large scale production and application of non-vanadium catalysts is still unpractical because of deactivation and inadequate oxidation efficiency, which becomes a big challenge for industrial-use of non-vanadium catalysts. For solid-state catalysts, the additive often plays an unexpected role on structural properties and catalytic performance. As an outstanding acid additive, Nb is often studied together with Ce, Mn, Co oxides to enhance the acidity properties of catalysts [18–21]. Besides, Nb has similar outer-shell electrons with V, so as to similar properties, and it would heavily promote the catalytic activity of Ce, Mn, Co oxides. Qu et al. [22] prepared CeNb mixed oxide catalysts, and the acid property of the catalyst was mainly provided by Nb oxides. Specifically, Nb−OH group was concerned with Brønsted acid site and Nb-O group with Lewis acid site. Sun et al. [23] investiaged the effect of Nb on Mn/TiO2 catalyst. They found that chemcial adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface were promted by introducing Nb into Mn/TiO2. Besides, the adding of Nb catalyst also remarkably increased the surface acidity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. As we know, the decomposition of CVOCs contains two steps: in the first step, chlorinated hydrocarbon molecular adsorbs on the acid site of catalyst surface to from hydrocarbon intermediate by breaking CCl bond; in the second step, the adsorbed hydrocarbon intermediate is further oxidized to CO2, H2O on the redox site [24–26]. Hence, in this work, oredered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 materials were synthesized by evaporation–induced self–assembly (EISA) method (Fig. 1 ). CeNb/TiSi catalysts with highly dispersed Ce oxides doped Nb supported on ordered mesoporous carriers were prepared via impregnation method. Then they were evaluated for catalytic oxidation elimination of Cl-VOCs and VOCs. By adjusting Ti/Si and Ce/Nb ratios, the structures and properties of CeNb/TiSi were controlled. The physicochemical properties, element electronic information, redox and acid properties of CeNb/TiSi catalysts were characterized by XRD, Raman, TEM, XPS and temperature–programmed technologies. MvK reaction mechanism was proposed by analyzing active sites for catalytic elimination of oDCB over CeNb/TiSi catalysts, in which surface lattice oxygen plays a significant role. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation TiO2–SiO2 ordered mesoporous support was synthesized by evaporation–induced self–assembly method according to our previous report [27]. In a typical process, 1.16 g P123 was firstly dissolved in 10 mL anhydrous ethanol by ultrasonic. After stirring for 30 min, a certain amount of TEOS and TBOT were dropped into the ethanol solution as well as 2.58 mL concentrated HCl. 3 h later, the transparent pale-yellow liquid was aged in a Petri dish for 5 days at 40 °C with relative humidity of 60%. At last, as-prepared white gel was dried at 80 °C for 24 h and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. The resulting white flaky material was ordered mesoporous TiO2–SiO2, which noted as TiaSib (a and b represented the molar ratio of Ti to Si). CeNb/TiSi oxide catalysts were prepared via impregnation method. Typically, a calculated amount of Ce(C2H3O2)3·nH2O and Nb(HC2O4)5·nH2O were dissolved in 5 mL deionized water, and then 3 mL concentrated HCl was added. After the precursor was completely dissolved, 1.5 g TiO2–SiO2 support was added under vigorous stirring. After 5 h later, it was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 450 °C for 4 h. The calcination products were marked as CexNby/TiSi (x and y were the weight percentages of Ce and Nb). 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Characterization technology of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is in supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements Activity evaluation of CeNb/TiSi catalysts for o-DCB elimination is described in supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterizations 3.1.1 Textural properties of samples Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore diameter distributions of CeNb/TiSi samples. All CeNb/TiSi catalysts give type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop which transforms from type III to II with the increase of Si content. This phenomenon signifies that the pore structure of CeNb/TiSi catalysts evolves from slit shape to “ink bottle-like”. The former comes from agglomeration of irregular flakes, the later from aggregation of homogeneous nano particles. Pore size of all samples is very broad and range from 2.5 to 10 nm, but they shift to small pore size with increasing Si content in CeNb/TiSi catalysts (Table 1 ). The pore volume of CeNb/TiSi catalysts gives an opposite change to pore size, and they gradually increase with the Si content. The specific surface area of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 is very small, but it sharply increases when Si is introduced. The largest specific surface area is 337 m2/g, which is observed on the sample with the highest Si content. The results above illustrate that the adding of Si into Ti oxide is conducive to specific surface area. The influence of Ce and Nb loadings on pore structure is negligible as shown in Fig. S1, whereas it is obvious on surface area. The catalysts with high Ce or Nb loadings exhibit a lower surface area compared to Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti7Si3 (Table 1). The NbOx surface density is displayed in Table 1, and it declines with the increase of Si and Ce content. Phase structure of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is investigated by XRD technology as shown in Fig. 3 . Only the diffractive peaks corresponding to A-TiO2 (Anatase, PDF# 21-1272) and R-TiO2 (Rutile, PDF# 21-1276) are observed. As demonstrated by the strong intensity, R-TiO2 is main crystal phase in four CeNb/TiSi catalysts with different Si/Ti ratio. No diffractions attributed to Si, Ce, or Nb are found, because Si, Ce, or Nb oxides are prone to amorphous structures according to previous literatures [28–30]. On the other hand, Ce and Nb oxides might be exist in highly dispersed due to the high specific surface area of TiO2-SiO2 carriers. In Fig. 3, diffractive intensity of TiO2 gradually increases with Ti content, indicating that large size grains of TiO2 form in high content of Ti samples. The effect of Ce and Nb loadings on XRD patterns is showed in Fig. S2, which has similar diffraction peaks to Fig. 3 and peak intensity keeps unchanged, illustrating that the adding of Ce and Nb oxides have nothing effect on the phase structure of TiO2-SiO2 support. The lattice structure of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is also probed by Raman spectra in Fig. 4 , which is a perfect supplement to XRD patterns. Peak intensity of Raman spectra gradually become sharp with increase of Ti content, and the reason is that the sample with high Ti content has small specific surface and well crystallinity. CeNb/TiSi samples with different Ti/Si molar ratios are characterized by the peaks at 143 and 516 cm−1 corresponding to Eg and B1g modes of A-TiO2, respectively. Besides, two weak peaks at 396 and 641 cm−1 in Fig. S3 are also attributed to B1g and Eg modes of A-TiO2. A weak line is observed with broad FWHM at 238 cm−1, which could be ascribed to a multi-phonon processes of TiO2 [31]. The strong peak with wavenumber of 446 cm−1 can be refered to F2g Raman active mode from symmetrical stretching vibration of Ce-O-Ce in eightfold coordination [32]. In terms of unitary CeO2, Raman active mode of F2g appears at 464 cm−1 [33,34], but the peak sharp and positions often change under the influence of particle size and lattice distortion [35,36]. For CeNb/TiSi samples, the red shift is observed on F2g Raman adsorption band from 464 to 446 cm−1. Low content and highly dispersed structure of Ce oxides on high specific surface area TiO2-SiO2 leads to decreased particle size, which will responsible for the red shift of F2g mode. Another factor of F2g red shift might be the incorporation of Nb atom into Ce oxide lattice, which destroys the symmetry of Ce-O-Ce unit and causes the distortion of Ce oxides lattice. The results above also signify that there are the interaction between Ce and Nb ions in CeNb/TiSi catalystys. The distinct Raman adsorption band at 608 cm−1 and a weak peak at 833 cm−1 are attributed to Nb-O bond from slightly distorted octahedral NbO6 (A in Scheme 1 ) and Nb-O bond from stretch vibration of NbO4 [37,38], respectively. According to literature [38], NbO4 only appears in isolated monomeric Nb species (B in Scheme 1), and it derives from Nb5+/Ce3+ redox reaction on oxygen vacancy. On high content of Ti and Nb samples (Figs. 4 and S3), a new Raman peak is observed at about 922 cm−1, which is ascribed to stretch vibration of Nb-O in monomeric NbO6 accompanied with Nb = O bond (C in Scheme 1) [38,39]. Raman spectron results above indicate that Nb oxides exist in highly dispersed structure and only monomeric Nb species forms on TiO2-SiO2 surface. Morphology and structure information of CeNb/TiSi catalysts with different Ti/Si molar ratios is further investigated by TEM and SAED in Fig. 5 a–d. Ordered mesoporous pore structure can be observed in the CeNb/TiSi catalysts except Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti4Si6. This result testifies that ordered mesoporous materials of TiO2 doped Si are successfully synthesized by EISA method. Optimum ordered structure is found in the sample with Ti/Si molar ratio of 8:2 as shown in Fig. 5b, which is related with its medium crystallinity. Since semicrystalline wall structure is benefit to the formation of ordered mesoporous, and high or low crystallinity will cause the collapse of ordered pore structure [40]. “Worm-like” pore structure forms in Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti4Si6, indicating that the doping of superabundant Si will destruct the ordering of TiO2-SiO2 pore structure. SAED inserted in TEM transforms from clear diffraction circles in Fig. 5a to a blurry shadow in Fig. 5d, illustrating that the crystallinity of CeNb/TiSi samples decreases with Si content, in line with the results of XRD. The element distribution of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti8Si2 catalyst is characterized by mapping plots (Fig. 5f–j), in which all elements are homogeneous distributing in mesoporous structure. This observation signifies that ordered pores of TiO2-SiO2 mesoporous material are uniformly composed of Ti and Si elements and Ce and Nb species uniformly locate on the surface of TiO2-SiO2 carriers. 3.1.2 Surface information of samples Electron information and element interactions on the surface of CeNb/TiSi catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . O1s XPS of CeNb/TiSi catalysts are showed in Fig. 6a. Three peaks attributed to Olatt, Osur, and Oads are obtained by deconvoluting CeNb/TiSi samples containing Si, while only Olatt and Osur species are observed in Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0. The Olatt peaks at the position of 530.2 ± 0.2 eV can be attributed to surface lattice oxygen, and the Osur bands with the binding energy of 531.9 ± 0.2 eV represent surface adsorbed oxygen including O2– and O–, for the Oads peaks, which is characteristic of physically adsorbed oxygen, such as water and hydroxyl [41,42]. It is worth noting that Oads species occurs together with the introduction of Si and increases with Si content, so Oads might come from physically adsorbed water or hydroxyl on Si atoms. The content variation of surface oxygen is listed in Table 2 . It is obvious that Olatt content of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 considerably higher than catalysts doped Si, and it gradually decreases with the increase of Si content. Used catalysts are also characterized and labeled as u-CeNb/TiSi. Compared with fresh catalysts, Olatt contents of used catalysts are all decreased (Table 2). In CeNb/TiSi samples, Osur species increases when Si is introduced and it continuously declines because of the increase of Oads with the Si content. Furthermore, the positions of three oxygen species is all shift to high binding energy with Si content due to the increase of physically adsorbed water or hydroxyl. O1s XPS results reveal that the introduction of Si has a significant impact on oxygen species contents and binding energy on the surface of CeNb/TiSi catalysts. Ce3d XPS profiles are displayed in Fig. 6b. Four pairs of orbit split doublets consisting of two Ce3+ and six Ce4+ peaks are observed by fitting Ce3d lines [43,44]. The peaks belonging to Ce3+ are marked as v0 (886.1 ± 0.2 eV) and u0 (904.9 ± 0.4 eV). The peaks corresponding to Ce4+ are labelled as v, v1, v2, u, u1, and u2 located at the positions of 882.9 ± 0.1, 888.9 ± 0.4, 899.0 ± 0.2, 901.5 ± 0.4, 908.5 ± 0.5, and 917.4 ± 0.2 eV. The molar ratios of Ce3+/Ce4+ are listed in Table 2, where the sample without Si has lower Ce3+/Ce4+ than other samples with Si. Additionally, Ce3+/Ce4+ ratios of used catalysts increase compared to parallel fresh catalysts. The transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ would produce oxygen vacancy to balance charge, and Ce3+ often relates to oxygen vacancy [45]. Fig. 6c exhibits the XPS of Nb3d, where two obvious peaks assigned to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 are presented. In four CeNb/TiSi catalysts, Nb5+ is main component, and the shoulder peaks at low binding energy are attributed to Nb4+ which origins from the redox reaction following: Ce3+ + Nb5+ = Ce4+ + Nb4+, indicating the strong interaction between and Ce and Nb, in line with the results of Raman spectra. Similar to oxygen species, the binding energy of Ce (Table 2), Nb (Fig. 6c), Ti (Fig. S4a), and Si (Fig. S4b) ions all increase when Si is introduced, which can be explained by the increase of physically adsorbed water or hydroxyl on CeNb/TiSi surface. Cl2p XPS of used CeNb/TiSi catalysts is showed in Fig. 6d. Cl2p1/2 and Cl2p3/2 peaks are observed at the positions with binding energy of 199.9 ± 0.2 and 198.4 ± 0.2 eV in u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 and u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4. It is apparent that the peak intensity of u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 is stronger than that of u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4 sample. The area of Cl2p3/2 peak of u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4 is only 0.7 of u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0. For XPS characterization, peak intensity and area represent the content of detected ions, so the results of Cl2p XPS demonstrate that more Cl species are presented on u-Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 catalyst. 3.1.3 Redox and acid properties of samples Redox properties of CeNb/TiSi catalysts are measured by H2-TPR technology as shown in Fig. 7 . For clarity, the H2-TPR profiles of CeNb/TiSi catalysts are deconvoluted into four peaks marked as α, β, γ, and η, respectively. The specific peak area and positions of H2-TPR line are listed in Table S1. As shown in Fig. 7 and Table S1, the total peak area of CeNb/TiSi H2-TPR curves gradually increase with the Si content, and the reducibility of samples decreases as the order of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti4Si6 > Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4 > Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti8Si2 > Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0. The area of β peak also increase with Si content, while the area of γ and η peaks exhibits an opposite variation. According to previous reports [46,47], Nb oxides is more difficult to be reduced than Ce oxides, pure Nb oxides are hardly reduced below 800 °C. Thus, the α reduction peaks could be attributed to chemically adsorbed oxygen molecular, and β peaks correspond to the reduction of surface oxygen species including hydroxyl, O2– and O–. The γ and η peaks can be assigned to the reduction of surface and bulk lattice oxygen, respectively. In H2-TPR, the area of reduction peak represents the content of reduced materials. What is worth noticing that the variation of reduction area for β and γ peaks is consistent with correspondent oxygen species, which further confirms the identification of these reduction peaks. For the reduction temperature, Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 is the lowest among four samples, which increase its redox efficiency. The reduction of γ peaks for all samples shifts to high temperature because of increased surface oxygen species belonging to β peaks (Fig. 7). The H2-TPR curves of CeNb/TiSi catalysts with different Ce/Nb ratios are displayed in Fig. S5. Reduction shape and temperature almost keep unchanged with the increase of Nb content, whereas reduction area of curves decreases with the increase of Nb content. The results of H2-TPR above illustrate that Si has significant influence on reduction temperature and area which is also determined by Nb content. Oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is evaluated by O2-TPD in Fig. S6. Two obvious O2 desorbed peaks are obvious at 516 and 685 °C, which could be ascribed to the desorption of chemically adsorbed oxygen atom (O−) and surface lattice oxygen. The desorption peak area of surface lattice oxygen decreases with Si content, whereas it is increase for chemically adsorbed oxygen atom in Fig. S6, in agreement with H2-TPR results. A small peak on Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4 at low temperature is the desorption of chemically adsorbed oxygen molecular (O2 −), which is not found on other samples. During the measurement of O2-TPD, oxygen desorption signal is weak, signifying that OSC of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is insufficient. NH3-TPD technology is taken to measure acid properties of CeNb/TiSi catalysts in Fig. 8 . Three NH3 desorbed peaks can be observed in NH3-TPD profiles, and the sharp peaks at 218 °C is NH3 desorption from weak acid sites, for the shoulder peaks at 319 °C, which can be attributed to moderate acid sites. The broad bands occur between 450 and 800 °C with a maximum at 669 °C belong to strong acid sites. In Fig. 8a, three types of acid sites gradually increase with the Si content in CeNb/TiSi catalysts. However, on CeNb/TiSi catalysts with different Ce/Nb ratios in Fig. 8b, only moderate and strong acid sites increase with Nb content which has no impact on the intensity of weak acid sites. This result manifests that the weak acid sites derive from Si hydroxyl, whereas the moderate and strong acid sites come from Nb oxides. 3.2 Catalytic elimination performance of samples Catalytic elimination performance of o-DCB over CeNb/TiSi catalysts is evaluated as shown in Fig. 9 a. Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 sample without Si exhibits optimum catalytic oxidation efficiency of o-DCB with T50 and T90 at 297 and 335 °C (Table 3 ), respectively. The catalytic oxidation activity of o-DCB over CeNb/TiSi catalysts decreases with the increase of Si in catalysts. Thus, we can know that catalytic elimination activity of o-DCB shows an opposite variation to its specific surface area and acidity, testifying that these factors are not key points to influence decomposition efficiency of o-DCB over CeNb/TiSi catalysts. According to the result of O1s XPS, large amount of surface lattice oxygen is responsible for the high activity of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0. The fact that Olatt decreases with the increase of Si content or after reaction further confirms the conclusion above. This conclusion also demonstrates that catalytic oxidation reaction of o-DCB over CeNb/TiSi catalysts fits with Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) reaction mechanism [48,49]. In this mechanism (Fig. 10 ), four step reactions occur on CeNb/TiSi catalysts. In the first step, carbocation jointed with Cl− is attacked by O− or O2- species on the catalyst surface and o-DCB is adsorbed on CeNb/TiSi catalysts via nucleophilic substitution with Cl- depositing on Ce cations or oxygen vacancies; in the second step, adsorbed o-DCB is oxidized to intermediate by surface lattice oxygen; in the third step, the intermediate is further oxidized to CO2, H2O, and HCl by surface lattice oxygen with the formation of oxygen vacancies; in the last step, surface lattice oxygen are replenished by gas O2. In the proposed reaction mechanism, the oxidation process of adsorbed o-DCB including the second and third step is rate-determining step, in which surface lattice oxygen plays a significant role. The surface lattice oxygen closely related to Si content in CeNb/TiSi, suggesting that the interaction between CeNb oxides and TiO2-SiO2 is important on catalytic elimination reaction of o-DCB. For the CeNb/TiSi catalysts with different Ce/Nb ratios, the best catalytic oxidation activity of o-DCB is obtained on Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti7Si3 because of its large specific surface area and strong interaction between Ce and Nb (Fig. 9b). According to the Raman results, monomeric NbO6 accompanied with NbO bond (C in Scheme 1) is presented in high Ti and Nb content samples including Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 and Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti7Si3, which might be another important factor on catalytic elimination of o-DCB. The selectivity of o-DCB catalytic elimination reaction is showed in Fig. S7. The main products are HCl and CO2, and only trace of Cl2 and chlorobenzene are detected on Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 at high temperature, which indicating a total oxidation of o-DCB over CeNb/TiSi catalyst. o-DCB catalytic elimination on CeNb/TiSi catalyst is compared with previous reports (Table 4 ). For these catalysts with same o-DCB concentration (1000 ppm), though the T50 of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 is not the lowest, its T90 exhibits the lowest temperature. The results above indicate outstandingly total decomposition activity of o-DCB over Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0, and even it is comparable to vanadium-based catalyst [50]. Fig. 9c displays stability of CeNb/TiSi catalysts with 90% initial conversion of o-DCB. After about 1500 min on stream, the activity of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 loss over 17%, and it only reduces 3–4% for the samples with high content of Si. Though the catalytic activity is inferior for the samples with high Si content, they exhibit an outstanding stability during reaction. The reason is that less Cl species is deposited on high Si sample than Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 according to the results of Cl XPS (Fig. 6d), which indicates that Si has preferable chlorine-resistant ability during catalytic oxidation reaction of o-DCB. To simulate real fluent gas, water-resistant stability is tested with water content of 5 vol. % in Fig. 9d. An interesting phenomenon is that the activity of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 is increased, while it is decreased on Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4 when water is introduced. A conceivable interpretation is that the presence of water promotes removal of deposited Cl− by hydrolysis from the surface of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 [52,54]. For Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4, active site of o-DCB is occupied by water molecular on account of its plentiful Si hydroxyl. After stopping introducing water, the catalytic activity of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 decreases due to its bad stability, and the catalytic activity of Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4 recovers to some extent. The catalytic activity of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is evaluated for VOCs without chlorine in Fig. 11 a. CeNb/TiSi catalysts completely destruct toluene with a T90 of 314 and 332 °C over Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 and Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti6Si4, respectively. Compared to o-DCB, CeNb/TiSi catalysts exhibit better catalytic activity for toluene. The results above testify that the catalytic elimination of Cl-VOCs is more difficult than VOCs, in line with the report on Ce-Mn oxides [55]. Without the impact of chlorine, CeNb/TiSi catalysts show an excellent stability for VOC catalytic oxidation (Fig. 11b), and its activity keeps unchanged holding for 700 min. 3.3 Kinetic analysis of o-DCB catalytic elimination on CeNb/TiSi catalysts In catalytic elimination reaction of o-DCB, 20 vol. % of O2 is taken, and the concentration of o-DCB is only 1000 ppm which could be neglected compared with O2, so the catalytic oxidation of o-DCB can be studied as first order reaction in kinetics. The apparent activation energies (Ea) of CeNb/TiSi catalysts are obtained by Arrhenius equations in our previous work [27]. Fig. 12 a shows that excellent linear relationship is presented between ln r and 1000/T with pearson correlation coefficient over -0.95 for all CeNb/TiSi catalysts. The Ea of CeNb/TiSi catalysts is given in Table 3. The smallest Ea of 54.5 kg/mol is obtained on Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0, and it increases with the Si content, in consistent with T90. The results above signify that the catalyst with low Ea is conducive to catalytic elimination reaction of o-DCB. The reaction rate (r) and TOF are calculated with o-DCB conversion at 280 °C (Table 3), where the sample with better o-DCB catalytic oxidation activity gives high reaction rate and TOF. Ce12.5Nb2.5/Ti10Si0 shows an optimum reaction rate of 0.094 μmol/(m2 s), TOFCe of 0.026 μmol/(m2 s), and TOFNb of 0.025 μmol/(m2 s). By fitting function profile between Olatt content and r, TOF, or Ea (12b and Fig. S8), a well linear relationship can be observed, further illustrating that surface lattice oxygen plays a significant role in catalytic elimination r of o-DCB. 4 Conclusions Ordered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 materials with high specific area were synthesized by evaporation–induced self–assembly method. With ordered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 as carriers, CeNb/TiSi catalysts were prepared via impregnation method, and it exhibited outstanding catalytic elimination performance for o-DCB. Ce and Nb oxides were highly dispersed on the surface of TiO2-SiO2. Nb oxides only existed in monomeric formation on TiO2-SiO2 surface with three Nb-O species, which contributes to moderate and strong acid sites. For the weak acid sites, which were derived from Si hydroxyl and increased with Si content. Surface lattice oxygen increased with Ti content, which played a significant role in catalytic oxidation elimination of o-DCB. Monomeric NbO6 accompanied with Nb = O bond and the interaction between CeNb oxides and TiO2-SiO2 was conducive to catalytic elimination of o-DCB. Optimum catalytic activity was observed on the sample with high content of Ti with a T90 of 335 °C, while it was susceptible to deposition of Cl− and lost its catalytic activity. The catalyst with high content of Si exhibit excellent chlorine-resistant ability during catalytic oxidation reaction of o-DCB. The catalytic elimination of CVOCs was more difficult than VOCs without chlorine over CeNb/TiSi catalysts. Catalytic oxidation reaction of o-DCB followed MvK reaction mechanism, in which surface lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen was active sites. coredata.dc:description: Ordered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 materials with high specific area were synthesized by evaporation–induced self–assembly (EISA) method. CeNb/TiSi catalysts were prepared via impregnation method and evaluated for catalytic elimination of 1,2-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB). The structures and properties of CeNb/TiSi were controlled by adjusting Ti/Si and Ce/Nb molar ratios and characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, TEM, Raman, XPS and temperature-programmed technology. Results showed that Ce and Nb oxides were highly dispersed on the surface of TiO2-SiO2 carriers due to its high specific surface area. Nb oxides was not only contributed to moderate and strong acid sites but also conducive to the catalytic elimination of o-DCB. Weak acid sites mainly derived from hydroxyl on the surface of Si. The catalyst without Si exhibited an optimum elimination efficacy of o-DCB but bad stability due to the deposition of Cl−, while the sample with high content of Si had excellent stability on account of the preferable chlorine-resistant ability of Si in catalytic elimination reaction o-DCB. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism of o-DCB catalytic elimination was proposed, in which surface lattice oxygen played a role of redox sites.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic performance of Nb doping Ce supported on ordered mesoporous TiO2-SiO2 catalysts for catalytic elimination of 1,2-dichlorobenzene
